author: Madeleine van Niekerk
title: Rand firmer amid volatile trade ahead of US Fed rate decision | Markets
text:
Picture: REUTERS Related articles Bonds weaker as Brazil is cut to ‘junk’ status THE rand was firmer late on Thursday amid volatile trade ahead of the US Federal Reserve’s rate hike decision next week.
Nervousness ahead of the Federal open market committee (FOMC) meeting is contributing to higher volatility in emerging market currencies.
Stockbrokerage Imara SP Reid said an improvement in volatility was only likely to emerge in the wake of the FOMC meeting once a greater degree of clarity emerged regarding the near-term interest-rate trajectory in the US.
A hike in US interest rates would most certainly buoy the dollar and subsequently weigh on the rand and local bonds.
At 3.30am, the rand was at R13.7899 to the dollar from Wednesday’s close of R13.7978. It touched a weakest intraday level of R13.9671 to the greenback.
Against the euro the rand was at R15.449 from R15.4589 previously and was at R21.2331 against the pound from a previous close of R21.1964.
The euro was at $1.1203 from a previous close of $1.1207.
Bidvest Bank head of foreign exchange Ion de Vleeschauwer said emerging market currencies faced pressure, but the rand was not the worst performing Brics (Brazil, Russia, India, China and SA) currency.
"Others currencies have fallen further, so there is still potential for a further rand slide. Of course, the rand might strengthen. No one can predict currency movements," Mr de Vleeschauwer said.
The rand largely ignored South African July manufacturing and mining production figures released by Statistics SA on Thursday.
Manufacturing production numbers were up 5.6% year on year from -0.5% in June and July mining production gained 5.6% year on year from 5.4% in June.
